# Continuous random variable

We define the **cumulative distribution function (cdf)**:
$$
P(x) = \mbox{Pr}(X \le x)
$$

The **probability density function (pdf)** is defined as the derivative of the cdf:
$$
p(x) \triangleq \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}P(x)
$$

For any continuous random variable it holds that:
$$
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x)\ \mathrm{d}x = 1
$$

and $p(x) \ge 0$.

## Uniform distribution

$$
\begin{align}
X &\sim \mbox{Uniform}(a, b) \\
p(x \mid a, b) &= \frac{1}{b - a}, \quad a \le x \le b
\end{align}
$$

## Exponential distribution

The exponential distribution can be used to model events that occur at a particular rate. For example, the waiting time for the bus the come.

$$
\begin{align}
X &\sim \mbox{Exp}(\lambda) \\
p(x \mid \lambda) &= \lambda e^{-\lambda x}, \quad x \ge 0 \\
\mathbb{E}[X] &= 1 / \lambda \\
\mathbb{V}[X] &= 1 / \lambda^{2}
\end{align}
$$

## Normal distribution

$$
\begin{align}
X &\sim \mbox{Normal}(\mu, \sigma) \\
p(x \mid \mu, \sigma) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi} \sigma} \exp\left\{-\frac{1}{2 \sigma^{2}} \left(x - \mu\right)^{2}\right\} \\
\mathbb{E}[X] &= \mu \\
\mathbb{V}[X] &= \sigma^{2}
\end{align}
$$
